questions.text: A 20-year-old man from West Bengal presents with recurrent fever with chills for the past 3 months with progressive weakness and abdominal discomfort. On examination, he has hepatosplenomegaly. Bone marrow aspiration finding is shown in the image below. Which of the following skin tests can be used to know the prior exposure to this parasite?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a 20-year-old man presenting with fever with chills, progressive weakness, and abdominal discomfort for the past 3 months and the bone marrow aspirate showing Leishman-Donovan bodies are suggestive of visceral leishmaniasis. A positive Montenegro skin test indicates prior exposure to the leishmanial parasite.

Leishmaniasis is a slowly progressing indigenous disease caused by a protozoan parasite of the genus Leishmania. It is transmitted by the bite of an infected female Phlebotomus sandfly, which inoculates the flagellated promastigotes into the skin of the host in developing countries. In India, it is endemic to Bihar, West Bengal, Jharkhand, and Uttar Pradesh.

Causative organisms include:

  • Old world leishmaniasis: Leishmania donovani, Leishmania major, and Leishmania tropica
  • New world leishmaniasis: Leishmania mexicana complex and Leishmania braziliensis complex

The image given below shows a phlebotomus sandfly.

The image below shows Lutzomyia sandfly responsible for the New World cutaneous leishmanisis.

In human beings, the disease presents in four different forms with a broad range of clinical manifestations:

  • Visceral leishmaniasis/ kala-azar
  • Cutaneous leishmaniasis
  • Mucocutaneous leishmaniasis
  • Diffuse cutaneous leishmaniasis

The life cycle of Leishmania involves two forms:

  • The promastigote develops and lives extracellularly in the sandfly vector and
  • The amastigote multiplies intracellularly in the reticuloendothelial cells of the host.  

When the infected sandfly bites a person, infectious promastigotes are released into the host dermis along with the sandfly's saliva, which potentiates parasite infectivity. Amastigote form (as shown in the image below) is also known as the Leishman-Donovan (LD) body. It is an intracellular form found inside macrophages, monocytes, and reticuloendothelial cells. It contains a kinetoplast, which consists of a parabasal body and a blepharoplast. Flagellum is absent.

Promastigote form (as shown in the below image) is present in the midgut of the female sandfly. The kinetoplast lies transversely near the anterior end. A single flagellum is seen. It is the infective form of L. donovani for humans.

Given below is the lifecycle of L. donovanii.

This condition causes fever with rigor and chills associated with splenomegaly and hepatomegaly. It lowers immunity and causes persistent fever, anaemia, leucopenia, and thrombocytopenia, if left untreated, death may occur due to opportunistic infection.

Diagnosis of kala-azar is mainly by demonstration of amastigotes within macrophages in tissue aspirates such as blood smears, bone marrow, splenic, or lymph node aspirate. It is the gold standard for diagnosis.

The image below shows amastigotes located intracellularly within macrophages.

Tests to detect leishmaniasis include:

  • Rapid diagnostic test: rK39 Rapid diagnostic test and Kala-azar dipstick test strip. This is recommended by the National Vector Borne Disease Control Programme (NVBDCP) in India.
  • Parasitological diagnosis: Demonstration of LD bodies in buffy coat smear - confirmatory.
  • Aldehyde test of Napier: Widely used for surveillance.
  • Serological tests for diagnosis: Rapid dipstick test, Direct agglutination test, ELISA, indirect fluorescent antibody test
  • Leishmanin (Montenegro) test: A skin test, 0.1 ml of killed promastigote suspension is injected intradermally on the dorsoventral aspect of foremarmInduration of 5mm or more is considered positive and indicates prior exposure to the leishmanial parasite. In active kala azar, this test is negative and becomes positive after 6-8 weeks (delayed hypersensitivity) after a cure from the disease or if the patient developed protective immunity.

Drugs used in the treatment of visceral leishmaniasis are

  • Sodium stibogluconate - Drug of choice in countries where strains are sensitive to antimony compounds.
  • Miltefosine - Alternative to sodium stibogluconate and only oral drug used in Kala-azar.
  • Amphotericin B - Drug of choice in India, as 40-60% of strains are resistant to antimony compounds. Liposomal amphotericin single dose 10 mg/kg IV is the first line of treatment in India, 

Other options:  

Option A: Frenkel's test is done in toxoplasmosis.

Option C: Fairley's test is done in schistosomiasis.

Option D: Bachman intradermal test done in trichinellosis.

Related Pearl: Sandfly

  • They are also referred to as Phlebotomus.
  • They transmit diseases such as kala-azar (visceral leishmaniasis), Oriental sore, sandfly fever, and Oroya fever.
  • They are generally smaller than mosquitoes and are hairy insects.
  • They like to dwell in cracks and crevices in walls during the daytime. They are active during the night (nocturnal pests).
  • They do not fly for more than 50 yards.
  • They can be controlled by insecticides and also by proper sanitation.

Related Pearl: Various morphological stages of hemoflagellates

It is based on the arrangement of the flagella in relation to the position of the nucleus and its point of emergence from the cells.

Stage Morphological characteristics Seen in
Amastigote

Rounded or ovoid, without any external flagellum.

The nucleus, kinetoplast, and axial filaments can be seen.

The axoneme extends up to the anterior end of the cell

 Trypanosoma cruzi and Leishmania as the intracellular form in the vertebrate host.
Promastigote

Lanceolate in shape.

Antenuclear kinetoplast- kinetoplast is anterior to the nucleus near the anterior end of the cell, from which flagellum emerges.

There is no undulating membrane

 It is the infective stage of Leishmania, found in the insect vector as well as in cultures in­vitro.
Epimastigote

Elongated. 

Juxtanuclear kinetoplast - kinetoplast placed more posteriorly, close to and in front of the nucleus.

The flagellum runs alongside the body as a short undulating membrane, before emerging from the anterior end.

It is the form in which Trypanosoma brucei occurs in the salivary gland of the vector tsetse fly and Trypanosoma cruzi in the midgut of the vector reduviid bug.

Note: This stage is lacking in Leishmania.
Trypo-mastigote

This stage is elongated, spindle-shaped with a central nucleus.

Postnuclear kinetoplast - kinetoplast is posterior to the nucleus and situated at the posterior end of the body.

The flagellum runs alongside the entire length of the cell to form a long undulating membrane before emerging as a free flagellum from the anterior end.

This is the infective stage of trypanosomes found in arthropod vector and in the blood of an infected vertebrate.

Note: This stage is lacking in Leishmania. 

Related Pearl: Leishmania

New world Disease Old world
L.chagasi

  L. infantum
L. mexicana (Chiclero ulcer)
CL
 L. tropica (Delhi boil / oriental sore )

- DCL L. ethiopica
L. braziliensis (Espundia) MCL -
Lutzomiya Vector Phlebotomus

questions.text: Method of choice to sterilize the given instrument is:
questions.solution:
Isopropyl alcohol is the method of choice to sterilize clinical thermometer.

questions.text: A child was brought to your clinic with an erythematous rash on the cheek, which later spread downwards to involve his trunk and limbs. He has also had a low-grade fever, and mild upper respiratory tract infection for the past few days. The suspected organism contains:
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and image are strongly suggestive of erythema infectiosum. The image is showing the classical slapped cheek appearance. It is caused by Parvoviruses. Parvovirus B19 is a non-enveloped single-stranded DNA virus. 

Clinically, parvovirus B-19 infection may have several presentations:

Erythema infectiosum- Also known as the fifth disease. The incubation period after infection is typically around 1-2 weeks. The hallmark of erythema infectiosum is the characteristic rash, which appears initially as erythematous facial flushing, often described as a “slapped cheek” appearance. Later, the rash spreads rapidly or concurrently to the trunk and proximal extremities as diffuse macular erythema. The child may be febrile. 

Transient aplastic crisis- It may be seen in patients with underlying chronic hemolytic anaemia like sickle-cell disease, thalassemia, hereditary spherocytosis, and RBC enzyme deficiencies like pyruvate kinase deficiency. Patients with aplastic crisis appear ill with fever, malaise, and paleness with tachycardia and tachypnea due to profound anaemia. The rash may or may not be present. 

Pure red cell aplasia- Persistent Parvovirus B19 infection in immunocompromised patients can cause chronic suppression of bone marrow and chronic anaemia, leading to pure red cell aplasia.

Maternal infection is associated with non-immune fetal hydrops and intrauterine fetal demise.

The diagnosis of erythema infectiosum is made clinically and does not require investigations routinely. Detection of viral DNA in the blood by PCR or nucleic acid hybridisation may be done for immunocompromised cases or prenatal diagnosis of infection.

It is self-limited and resolves on its own. IVIG may be given to immunocompromised children.

Related Pearl: Enveloped and non-enveloped viruses

  Non-enveloped viruses Enveloped viruses

questions.text:
Which of the following agglutination patterns in the Weil-Felix Reaction will be seen in a patient diagnosed with scrub typhus?
  OX 19 OX 2 OX K
1. +++ + -
2. +++ +/- -
3 ++ ++  -
4. - - +++
questions.solution:
OX K agglutination in a Weil-Felix Reaction will be seen in a case of scrub typhus.

Scrub typhus is also known as chigger-borne typhus, which is caused by O. tsutsugamushi. The vector is trombiculid mite. Humans are infected when they are bitten by the mite larvae known as chiggers. 

The incubation period is 1–3 weeks. The patient typically develops a characteristic eschar at the site of the mite bite, with regional lymphadenopathy and maculopapular rash.

Weil-Felix reaction is a heterophile agglutination reaction, wherein the sera are tested for agglutinins to the O antigens of certain Proteus strains—Proteus vulgaris - OX 19 and OX 2 and Proteus mirabilis OX K. The basis of the test is sharing an alkali-stable carbohydrate antigen by some Rickettsiae and by some strains of Proteus. OX K is agglutinated only in scrub typhus.

Inference of Agglutination Pattern in Weil-Felix Reaction:

DISEASE          

OX 19

OX 2

OX K

Epidemic typhus

+++

+

-

Endemic typhus

+++

+/-

-

RMSF

++

++

-

Scrub typhus

-

-

+++

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the OPD with fever, earache, and stiffness on opening the mouth. On examination, the parotid gland is enlarged, as shown below, and tender. Choose the correct strain used to prepare a vaccine for this disease.
questions.solution:
The clinical diagnosis in this case, based on clinical features and image, is most likely Mumps. The strain used to prepare the Mumps vaccine is Jeryl Lynn. It is a live attenuated vaccine.

Mumps is an infectious disease caused by an RNA virus from the paramyxoviridae family. Infection is caused by air droplets through the respiratory route and also through the conjunctiva.

The incubation period is 12-25 days. Then parotid swelling appears first. It is unilateral, to begin with, but may become bilateral. Some patients may have a prodrome of fever and malaise before the swelling appears.

Major complications of Mumps include epididymal orchitis and meningoencephalitis.

Mumps vaccine is given only after one year of age because, before that, maternal antibodies may interfere with its action. It can be given separately or as a part of Measles, Mumps, Rubella (MMR) vaccine.

Other options:

Option A: Edmonston-Zagreb strain is used for the Measles vaccine.

Option B: The 17D strain is used for the Yellow fever vaccine.

Option C: The Oka strain is used for the Varicella vaccine.

Related Pearl: Vaccines and their Strains

questions.text: A young male patient presents with a high-grade fever, headache, and weakness for 4 days. The microscopic examination of the thin blood smear is given below. Which of the following is the definitive host of the causative agent?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario, along with the thin blood smear showing a maltese cross appearance, is suggestive of Babesia microti infection. The definitive host for Babesia is ixodid ticks, whereas humans are the incidental, dead-end hosts.

Babesia microti causes babesiosis. It is a zoonotic infection that resembles malaria and is transmitted by a bite of ixodid ticks. Patients present with febrile illness, headache, and weakness. Lab investigations show hemolysis and hemoglobinuria.

On microscopic examination by Giemsa stain, Babesia trophozoites appear as intraerythrocytic round or pyriform or ring form. The ring form is the most common, and it lacks the central hemozoin deposit, which differentiates it from P. falciparum. Other distinguishing features are the absence of schizonts and gametocytes and the presence of tetrads/ maltese crosses, which are pathognomic of B. microti or B. duncani.

The image given below shows the maltese cross appearance seen in infection with Babesia microti.

Other options:

Option A: Protozoan parasite Leishmania is transmitted by the bite of an infected female phlebotomus sandfly.

Option C: Plasmodium species is transmitted by the Anopheles mosquito.

Option D: Rickettsia akari is transmitted by Gamasid mites and causes rickettsial pox.

questions.text: Community weed removal from ponds for the control of a disease was documented in Shertallai, Kerala, India.  Which of the following water-related diseases can be controlled by this approach?
questions.solution:
Filariasis (caused by B.malayi ), a water-related disease, can be controlled by the removal of weeds from ponds. It is transmitted by the Mansonia species of mosquito that breeds in water bodies containing aquatic vegetation and can also be controlled by the use of herbicides that destroy aquatic vegetation.

Adult Mansonia mosquitos are big, black or brown mosquitoes with speckling on their wings and legs. They breed in ponds and lakes containing certain aquatic plants, especially the floating types like Pistia stratiotes and water hyacinth. Their breeding is not possible in absence of these plants. Thus, removing the aquatic vegetation and destroying the vegetation using herbicides can be done to control filariasis. 

The image below shows a picture of a Mansonia mosquito: 

Other options:

Option A: Weil's disease is a form of leptospirosis that occurs due to spirochaete Leptospira. It is excreted in the urine of infected animals for a long time.

Option C: Cholera is an acute diarrhoeal disease caused by Vibrio cholerae. It is usually acquired through contaminated water and food.

Option D: Giardiasis is a waterborne disease caused by protozoa Giardia intestinalis. It is acquired through contaminated food or water and causes diarrhoea.

Related Pearl: The Mosquito

The mosquito as a vector:

  • Mosquitoes are global in distribution
  • The main species of mosquitoes include the Anopheles, Culex, Aedes, and Mansonia
  • Flight range varies up to 11 km, except Aedes for which it is 100 meters
  • The life span of mosquitoes is around 8 to 34 days
  • Their morphology consists of a head with a proboscis, a pair of palpi, and a pair of antennae; a thorax and an abdomen
  • The larval stage lasts for 5 to 7 days

Characteristics:

Characteristics Anopheles Culex Aedes Mansonia

Eggs: 100-250. 

 Laid singly. Boat-shaped with lateral floats. Laid in clusters or rafts. Laid singly. Laid in star-shaped clusters.

Larval stage

No siphon tube.

Lies parallel to the undersurface of water.

Has siphon tube.

Lies in water with head faced downwards.

Has siphon tube.

Lies in water with head faced downwards.

Has siphon tube.

Lies in water with head faced downwards.
Adults Wings spotted. Wings unspotted. Wings unspotted. Striped body. Wings unspotted.
Breeding areas Clean water Dirty and polluted water Artificial collections of water Water bodies containing aquatic vegetation
Diseases Malaria, filaria Bancroftian filariasis, Japanese encephalitis, West Nile fever, viral arthritis. Yellow fever, dengue, DHF, chikungunya, rift valley fever, filariasis, Zika virus Malayan filariasis
Comments Anopheline mosquitoes tend to sit with their heads low and their rear ends raised high, especially when feeding. 

Called Nuisance mosquitoes

These culicine female mosquitoes keep their bodies horizontal while feeding.

Called tiger mosquitoes

Day biters

They get the tiger's name from the white stripes on its legs.

 Big, black, or brown mosquitoes with sparkling wings and legs. 

 

 

Culex mosquito keeps their bodies horizontal while feeding.

 Anopheles mosquito tends to sit at an angle, with their heads low and their rear ends raised high.

Aedes mosquito has a striped body pattern.

questions.text: You notice that an elderly patient in the neurology ward has fever for 3 days. He was admitted for a stroke 2 weeks ago. The blood culture shows no growth while the urine culture shows growth on the MacConkey agar as seen in the image below. Urease test is positive. What is the likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
The urine culture shows mucoid colonies on MacConkey agar, indicating that the organism is a lactose fermenter. Also, the urease test was positive. This suggests that a urinary tract infection occurred in a hospitalised patient, likely caused by Klebsiella. 

Klebsiella is the most common cause of catheter-associated urinary tract infections. It has the cultural characteristics of large mucoid colonies on MacConkey agar. Urease is positive only for Klebsiella, proteus and morganella in Enterobacteriaceae. 

Enterobacteriaceae family is classified based on their action on lactose present in MacConkey's medium:

  • Lactose fermenters - Escherichia, Klebsiella
  • Late lactose fermenters - Shigella sonnei (More than 12-24 hours)
  • Non-lactose fermenters- Salmonella species, Shigella species

Other options 

Option B: Escherichia coli is urease-negative and forms smooth, bright pink colonies on MacConkey agar

Options C and D: Proteus and pseudomonas are non lactose fermenters thus form pale colourless colonies on MacConkey agar.

questions.text: A 21-year-old male patient presented with low-grade fever, loss of weight, and dry nocturnal cough for the past 6 months. Physical examination wheezing and crepitations on chest auscultation and mild hepatosplenomegaly. Eosinophil count- 10000/mm3. Serology revealed high levels of IgE and positive for filarial antibodies. Which of the following is not true regarding this condition?

choices.text: It is directly due to lymphatic involvement
It is also known as Meyers Kouwenaar syndrome
Microfilaria cannot be demonstrated in blood
Diethylcarmazine is the treatment of choice

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a young adult with pulmonary symptoms, pronounced blood eosinophilia, elevated serum IgE, and anti-filarial antibodies are suggestive of Occult Filariasis, in this case, Tropical Pulmonary Eosinophilia. It occurs as a result of a hypersensitivity reaction to micro-filarial antigens, not directly due to lymphatic involvement.

Tropical pulmonary eosinophilia (TPE) is a hyperresponsive pulmonary syndrome in response to trapped microfilariae within the lung tissue. 

It is a manifestation of occult filariasis (also known as Meyer's-Kouwenaar syndrome). It occurs as a result of type 1 hypersensitivity reaction to micro-filarial antigens, not directly due to lymphatic involvement.

More common in children and young adults in filarial endemic zones.

Clinical manifestations:

  • Nocturnal paroxysmal wheeze and cough
  • Weight loss, low-grade fever, lymphadenopathy
  • Hepatosplenomegaly
  • Eosinophilia > 3000/μL, leucocytosis
  • X-ray chest: Mottled opacities similar to miliary TB, increased broncho-vascular markings
  • PFT: Restrictive changes in most cases and obstructive defects in half
  • Elevated levels of IgE and Antifilarial antibody titers
  • Microfilaria are sequestrated in the lungs and hence not found in blood

Treatment: Diethylcarbamazine(DEC)

Differntial Diagnosis:

  • Loffler syndrome
  • Allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis
  • Churg strauss syndrome
  • Chronic eosinophilic pneumonia
  • Hypereosinophilic syndromes

questions.text: A female patient presents to the physician with sudden-onset fever, rash, conjunctivitis, muscle and joint pain, malaise, and headache. On further evaluation, she tested positive for the Zika virus. She has an increased risk of developing which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The patient who tested positive for the Zika virus has an increased risk of developing Guillan-Barre syndrome.

Zika virus is a flavivirus acquired mainly through the bite of an infected female Aedes aegypti mosquito. However, transmission can also occur perinatally through sexual contact with an infected individual, breastfeeding, and blood transfusion. 

Congenital transmission of the Zika virus leads to fetal microcephaly. Zika virus infection during pregnancy may also lead to other malformations, including limb contractures, high muscle tone, eye abnormalities, and hearing loss, known as congenital Zika syndrome.

Zika virus infection is characterized by influenza-like clinical signs, including fever, headache, and malaise. An itchy, maculopapular rash, conjunctivitis, myalgia, and arthralgia usually accompany or follow those manifestations.

The complications of the Zika virus infection include Guillan-Barre syndrome, encephalitis, meningoencephalitis, peripheral neuropathies, and neurological birth defects. Other complications of pregnancy include preterm birth and miscarriage.

Other Options:

Option B: Glomerulonephritis is seen 1-4 weeks after the acute infection of Streptococcus pyogenes. 

Option C: Subacute sclerosing panencephalitis (SSPE) is a rare delayed sequel to infection with the measles virus. It is seen in young adolescents and is characterized by progressive deterioration of mental and motor functions.

Option D: Thyroiditis is not a known complication of Zika virus infection. Some viruses like mumps and influenza can cause subacute thyroiditis.

Related Pearl: Taxonomy of Arboviruses

questions.text: As a PHC officer, you conduct a session on viral diseases that are more likely to affect the rice farmers in your area. You focus on a disease which follows a bird-arthropod-human transmission route where man is an incidental dead-end host. Identify the disease.
questions.solution:
The viral disease discussed in the above scenario is Japanese encephalitis, which follows bird-arthropod-human transmission, where man is an incidental dead-end host. 

Japanese encephalitis (JE) is a mosquito-borne encephalitis caused by a group B arbovirus (Flavivirus) and transmitted by the bite of Culex mosquitoes, specifically Culex tritaeniorhynchus and Culex vishnui (common in India), which typically breed in irrigated rice fields. Therefore, rice farmers are more likely to be affected.

The image below shows the life cycle of the Japanese B encephalitis virus.

Clinical features include high fever, headache, and vomiting. Signs of encephalitis, such as convulsions, neck rigidity, and altered sensorium, appear after 1-6 days. 

Inactivated vero cell culture-derived SA-14-14-2 vaccine is approved for use in India. JE vaccine is given in two doses- at 9-12 months of age and at 16-24 months of age in areas that are endemic to the disease, according to the National Immunization Schedule. 

Other options:

Option A: Ebola virus belongs to the family Filoviridae and is transmitted by bats. Human-to-human transmission through blood or body fluids can occur. It causes fever, abdominal pain, diarrhoea, and haemorrhage. 

The image below shows the lifecycle of the ebola virus:

Option B: Nipah virus is a zoonotic virus, which is transmitted from pigs to humans. Fruit bats are the natural hosts. It causes severe encephalitis with high mortality. 

The image given below depicts the life cycle of the Nipah virus:

Option D: Zika virus is transmitted to human beings by the bite of an infected Aedes mosquito. It can also be transmitted trans-placentally, causing microcephaly and other severe fetal brain defects. 

Related Pearl: The Mosquito

The mosquito as a vector:

  • Mosquitoes are global in distribution
  • The main species of mosquitoes include the Anopheles, Culex, Aedes, and Mansonia
  • Flight range varies up to 11 km, except Aedes for which it is 100 meters
  • The life span of mosquitoes is around 8 to 34 days
  • Their morphology consists of a head with a proboscis, a pair of palpi, and a pair of antennae; a thorax and an abdomen
  • The larval stage lasts for 5 to 7 days

Characteristics:

Characteristics Anopheles Culex Aedes Mansonia

Eggs: 100-250. 

 Laid singly. Boat-shaped with lateral floats. Laid in clusters or rafts. Laid singly. Laid in star-shaped clusters.

Larval stage

No siphon tube.

Lies parallel to the undersurface of water.

Has siphon tube.

Lies in water with head faced downwards.

Has siphon tube.

Lies in water with head faced downwards.

Has siphon tube.

Lies in water with head faced downwards.
Adults Wings spotted. Wings unspotted. Wings unspotted. Striped body. Wings unspotted.
Breeding areas Clean water Dirty and polluted water Artificial collections of water Water bodies containing aquatic vegetation
Diseases Malaria, filaria Bancroftian filariasis, Japanese encephalitis, West Nile fever, viral arthritis. Yellow fever, dengue, DHF, chikungunya, rift valley fever, filariasis, Zika virus Malayan filariasis
Comments Anopheline mosquitoes tend to sit with their heads low and their rear ends raised high, especially when feeding. 

Called Nuisance mosquitoes

These culicine female mosquitoes keep their bodies horizontal while feeding.

Called tiger mosquitoes

Day biters

They get the tiger's name from the white stripes on its legs.

 Big, black, or brown mosquitoes with sparkling wings and legs. 

 

 

Culex mosquito keeps their bodies horizontal while feeding.

 Anopheles mosquito tends to sit at an angle, with their heads low and their rear ends raised high.

Aedes mosquito has a striped body pattern.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy returned from a birthday party and began vomiting 4-5 hours later, followed by a few episodes of loose stools, but had no fever. Other children who had attended the party reported a similar illness. Food samples were collected and sent for toxin detection by a test based on the following principle. This test is known as:
questions.solution:
The given image shows Sandwich ELISA. The above clinical scenario is suggestive of food poisoning caused by Staphylococcus aureus.

The symptoms of food poisoning caused by S aureus appear within 1-8 hours. Multiple people are exposed to the pathogen from a common source and present with vomiting, loose stools but no fever. Foods from outbreaks of food poisoning is examined for the presence of staphylococcal enterotoxin A (SEA) by a sandwich ELISA.

ELISA (Enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay) involves the use of an immunosorbent, which is an absorbing material that is specific for one of the components of the reaction, either the antigen or antibody. This may be a particulate phase (cellulose or agarose), or a solid phase (polystyrene, polyvinyl, or polycarbonate tubes or microwells). ELISA is done using 96-well microtitre plates suitable for automation.

Sandwich ELISA is used for antigen detection in the patient samples. The antigen is sandwiched between two layers of antibodies - capture and detection antibodies.

The following steps are followed in Sandwich ELISA:

  1. The capture antibody is immobilized on a microtiter well.
  2. A sample containing antigen is added and allowed to react with the immobilized antibody.
  3. After the well is washed, a second enzyme-linked antibody (Detecting antibody) specific to the antigen is added and allowed to react with the bound antigen.
  4. After any free second antibody is removed by washing, the substrate is added. This substrate is converted by the enzyme to detectable colored form and the colored reaction product is measured.

Other options:

Option A: Cassette ELISA: Here, each specimen is tested in a separate disposable cassette and gives rapid results (10-15 minutes). There is no need for microplate washers or readers and the result can be read visually. Example: Dot Blot Assay used for the detection of HIV type 1 and 2 antibodies.

Option C: Competitive ELISA: Both the unknown antigen (sample) and the known antigen (standard) compete with each other for a fixed amount of antibody.

Option D: Indirect ELISA: Antibody in the sample can be detected or quantitatively measured using this method. Serum or some other sample containing primary antibody (Ab1) is added to an antigen-coated microtiter well and allowed to react. Enzyme-conjugated secondary anti-isotype antibody (Ab2) is added which binds to the primary antibody.

The given image shows steps followed in different types of ELISA.

Related Pearl: Food Poisoning

Organism Symptoms Common food source
1–6 hrs incubation period  
Staphylococcus aureus Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea Ham, poultry, potato, cream pastries, mayonnaise
Bacillus cereus Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea Fried rice
8–16 hrs incubation period  
Clostridium perfringes Abdominal cramps, diarrhea Beef, poultry, legume, gravies
Bacillus cereus Abdominal cramps, diarrhea Meat, vegetables, dried beans, cereals
>16 hrs incubation period  
Vibrio cholerae Watery diarrhea Shellfish, water
Salmonella species Inflammatory diarrhea Beef, poultry, eggs
Enterotoxigenic Escherichia coli Watery diarrhea Salads, cheese, meats
Enterohemorrhagic E. coli Bloody diarrhea Raw milk, raw vegetables, apple juice
Campylobacter jejuni Inflammatory diarrhea Poultry, raw milk
Shigella species Dysentery Potato, egg salad, lettuce
Vibrio parahaemolyticus Dysentery Molluscs, crustaceans

questions.text: A woman from rural South America presents with shortness of breath and palpitations. Examination of the eye is shown in the image given below. Echocardiography reveals biventricular dilatation with massive cardiac enlargement. Which vector is most likely responsible for transmitting this patient's disease?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario, along with an image showing Romana’s sign and echo findings of dilated cardiomyopathy, are suggestive of Chagas disease. It is caused by Trypanosoma cruzi, transmitted by the reduviid bug.

Chagas disease is a zoonotic disease caused by the protozoa Trypanosoma cruzi. It is endemic to north, central, and south America. It is transmitted by the bite of a reduviid bug/ kissing bug.

Trypanosoma cruzi exists in three forms:

  • Epimastigotes- in the reduviid bug
  • Trypomastigotes- in the bloodstream
  • Amastigotes- intracellular replicating form

Clinically, the infection course of Chagas disease is divided into acute and chronic phases.

In the acute phase, the majority of the patients will be asymptomatic. Fever, regional lymphadenitis, chagoma (localised subcutaneous nodule at the bite site), and the Romaña's sign (unilateral swelling of the eyelids) may be seen in the acute phase. 

The chronic phase is characterised by the following findings:

  • Chagasic dilated cardiomyopathy with marked bilateral ventricular enlargement. This leads to leading to congestive heart failure, presenting as shortness of breath. Endomyocardial biopsy shows fibrosis and the presence of intracellular parasites.
  • Megaesophagus and megacolon. 

Diagnosis is confirmed by demonstrating trypomastigotes on microscopy of blood smears or polymerase chain reactions during the acute phase. In the chronic phase, detection of anti-T. cruzi IgG or endomyocardial biopsy is helpful.

Treatment of Chagas disease is most effective when administered early in the course of infection and has a lesser efficacy in chronic Chagas. Benznidazole and nifurtimox can be used for the treatment.

The image given below shows a reduviid bug.

Other options:

Option A: Dermacentor tick is a type of hard tick responsible for transmitting rocky mountain spotted fever.

Option B: Soft ticks are known to transmit relapsing fever.

Option D: Tsetse fly is responsible for transmitting Trypanosoma brucei rhodesiense and Trypanosoma brucei gambiense that cause African sleeping sickness.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child with excoriation of anal skin was brought by his mother to the pediatric OPD. She states her son scratches his anal area frequently during nighttime. The life cycle of the causative organism is given below. Which of the following is not a feature of the egg of this organism?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of frequent anal area scratching during nighttime, excoriation of the skin around the anus, and the given life cycle of humans acquiring infection by ingestion of embryonated eggs, which are released by the gravid female over the perianal skin are suggestive of pinworm or Enterobius vermicularis infection. The eggs of pinworms are not bile-stained.

The pinworm eggs have a characteristic plano-convex shape. They are colorless and not bile-stained. They have a thick, double-layered, transparent eggshell. The eggs also float in a saturated salt solution. Inside lies a tadpole-shaped coiled embryo. The eggs are highly infectious, and reinfection should be prevented by regular washing of bed linens, towels, and clothing in hot water.

Enterobius vermicularis completes its entire life cycle in the human host. Infection is acquired by ingesting embryonated eggs containing larva through contaminated fingers and by autoinfection. At night, the gravid female worm comes out through the anus, crawls around on the perianal and perineal skin, and lays its eggs. This leads to pruritus, and the patient scratches the affected perianal area. The worm can crawl into the vulva and vagina, causing irritation and a mucoid discharge. It can also cause chronic salpingitis, cervicitis, peritonitis, recurrent urinary tract infections, and appendicitis.

A faecal examination is not useful for diagnosis as the eggs are not usually released in faeces. The eggs can be demonstrated by swabbing the perianal and perineal skin where they are deposited. The adult worms may sometimes be noticed on the surface of stools, can be found crawling out of the anus, or may be detected in stools collected after an enema.

The NIH swab (National Institutes of Health, USA) is used to collect specimens for diagnosis. In the NIH swab, the perianal area is swabbed by rolling the cellophane part over it. After detaching the cellophane part, it is spread over a glass slide and examined microscopically. The image given below shows the NIH swab.

Another method is the scotch tape method, where the tape is firmly pressed against the anal margin, covering all sides. The tape is transferred to a glass slide with the sticky side down. Then, a drop of toluene is added for clearing and examined under the microscope.

Treatment involves a single dose of Pyrantel pamoate 11 mg/kg, albendazole 400mg, or mebendazole 100mg. Piperazine is given once daily for a week.

Related Pearl: Infective form and diagnostic forms - Worms

Parasite Infective form Diagnostic form

Trematode

Other trematodes - Fasciola hepatica, Fasciolopsis buski, Paragonimus westermani, Clonorchis sinensis Metacercaria larva Operculated Eggs
Nematode
Ascaris lumbricoides Egg Unembryonated eggs in stool

Ancylostoma duodenale

Necator americanus

Enterobius vermicularis Egg Eggs from perianal skin

Hint: The infective and diagnostic forms are usually the same in the parasites causing autoinfection.

questions.text: A patient from North America presented with acute pulmonary edema after an episode of fever, myalgia, and headache. He was found to be infected with the Sin Nombre virus. What type of virus is this?
questions.solution:
Sin Nombre virus is a type of Hantavirus. The given clinical feature is suggestive of Hantavirus pulmonary syndrome. 

Hantaviruses are classified under Bunyaviridae. They are rodent-borne viruses that are transmitted by inhalation of the virus contained in dried excreta of rodents. They are the natural pathogens of rodents like mice, rats, and voles. No human-to-human transmission is reported.

Clinical features: 

  • Hemorrhagic fever with renal syndrome (HFRS) -  Presents with acute kidney injury, hemorrhages, fever, and circulatory collapse
  • Hantavirus pulmonary syndrome (HPS) - Characterized by the acute onset of severe pulmonary edema after 3–4 days of a prodromal illness of fever, malaise, myalgia, and gastrointestinal symptoms

Laboratory diagnosis depends on viral nucleic acid detection by RT-PCR.

Hantaviruses are emerging pathogens that could be engineered for mass dissemination in the future because of availability, ease of production, dissemination, the potential for high morbidity and mortality rates, and major health impact. It is a category C bioterrorism agent.

Related Pearl: Bioterrorism Agents

Description Characteristics Examples
Category A

Capacity to get disseminated

Social disruption

Requires specialised public health resources

 

Bacillus anthracis

Clostridium botulinum

Yersinia pestis

Variola major

Francisella tularensis

Ebola and other hemorrhagic fevers

Lassa fever and other arenaviruses

 
Category B 

Minority priority agents

Moderately well disseminated

Moderate morbidity and low mortality

Require enhancement of CD and diagnostic capacity

Coxiella burnetti

Burkholderia mallei

Burkholderia pseudomallei

Ricin toxin

Cryptosporidium parvum

Salmonella typhi

Chlamydia psittaci
Category C

Low priority agents

Could be engineered for mass dissemination

Readily available

Easy to produce

Potentially high morbidity and mortality

 Emergent viruses -Nipah and Hantavirus

questions.text: A 30-year-old male is diagnosed with viral hemorrhagic fever. You suspect the Zaire strain of the virus to be responsible for the infection. The virus involved is highly virulent and morphologically appears as long filamentous threads. After further evaluation, you start him on Inmazeb. What family does the virus implicated in this condition belong to?
questions.solution:
In the above clinical scenario, the presence of viral hemorrhagic fever caused by Zaire strain of a highly virulent virus which, morphologically appears as long filamentous threads is highly suggestive of Ebola Virus which belongs to the Filoviridae family.

This diagnosis is confirmed by the drug used to treat this patient, Inmazeb (atoltivimab, maftivimab, and odesivimab), a mixture of three monoclonal antibodies, which is the first Food and Drug Administration(FDA) approved treatment for Zaire ebolavirus infection in adult and pediatric patients.

Ebola virus is the cause of an emerging disease called Ebola virus disease and is widespread in Africa. They are filamentous viruses with nonsegmented single-stranded RNA as genetic material.

Fruit bats act as reservoir hosts of the virus and it is transmitted to humans only accidentally. Human-to-human transmission is through direct contact with blood or body fluids of an infected symptomatic person. It can remain in semen for up to 3 months, although sexual transmission has not been reported yet.

The incubation period of the disease is 2 to 21 days. Symptoms include fever, intense weakness, vomiting, diarrhea, rashes, and, in extreme cases, internal and external bleeding. The current treatment is mainly supportive. Patients are susceptible to reinfection even after a complete cure.

Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) is a commonly used diagnostic method for Ebola disease because of its ability to detect low levels of an ebolavirus. 

Ebola virus is highly virulent and requires maximum containment facilities (Biosafety Level 4) for laboratory work and belongs to Category A (High risk) bioterrorism which poses a threat to national security and has the ability to cause social disruption.

Other options:

Option A: Flaviviridae family- Flaviviruses are enveloped viruses with a diameter of 40-60 nm and single-stranded, positive-sense RNA. Most members are transmitted by blood-sucking arthropods. They include yellow fever, dengue viruses, Japanese encephalitis virus and Hepatitis C virus.

Option B: Arenaviridae family-  Spherical or pleomorphic viruses, 50-300 nm in size. Only one genus, Arenavirus, has been recognised. Species include lymphocytic choriomeningitis virus(LCM) and Lassa virus.

Option D: Bunyaviridae family- Bunyaviruses are spherical or pleomorphic, 80- to 120-nm enveloped particles. The genome is made up of a triple-segmented, single-stranded RNA. The majority of these viruses are transmitted to vertebrates by arthropods (arboviruses). They include sandfly fever and hantaviruses.

Related Pearl: Taxonomy of Arboviruses

FAMILY

GENUS

IMPORTANT SPECIES

Togaviridae

Alphavirus

Chikungunya, Eastern equine encephalitis virus, Western equine encephalitis virus, Venezuelan equine encephalitis virus 

Flaviviridae

Flavivirus

Japanese encephalitis, West Nile virus, Dengue virus, Kayasanur forest disease virus, Murray valley encephalitis virus, Yellow fever virus, Zika virus

Bunyaviridae

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy complained of burning micturition and flank pain. The following day he started passing blood in the urine. The condition was diagnosed as acute hemorrhagic cystitis. In children, this can be caused by  _______
questions.solution:
Adenoviruses types 11 and 21 can cause acute hemorrhagic cystitis in children. They are a viral cause of urinary tract infections that can lead to cystitis and gross hematuria.

 Urinary tract infections in children are most commonly caused by the following:

  • Escherichia coli (Most common)
  • Klebsiella species
  • Proteus species
  • Staphylococcus saprophyticus
  • Enterococcus
  • Adenovirus and other viral infections (cause cystitis and gross hematuria)

Other options:

Option B: Norovirus or Norwalk virus can cause diarrhoea, vomiting, and gastroenteritis epidemics among children.

Option C: Enteroviruses comprise many viruses that can cause a variety of diseases, such as poliomyelitis, myocarditis, conjunctivitis, and pleurodynia.

Option D: Rotavirus is the most common cause of diarrhoea among infants and young children.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient who is on ART for AIDS presented with difficulty in vision. Fundoscopic examination revealed the following finding as shown in the image below. Which of the following subfamilies of the Herpesviridae family encompasses the causative agent?
questions.solution:
Pizza pie appearance on fundoscopy in an immunocompromised person is characteristic of cytomegalovirus (CMV) retinitis. It belongs to beta viruses subfamily of the Herpesviridae family.

Herpesviridae family is divided into 3 subfamilies:

  • Alpha herpesviruses (e.g. HSV 1 and 2, varicella-zoster virus)
  • Beta herpes viruses (e.g. CMV)
  • Gamma herpesviruses (e.g. EBV)

Alpha viruses

 Beta viruses Gamma viruses
Short replicative cycle – 12-18 hours Replicative cycle - >24 hours variable
Latency – sensory ganglia Latency – salivary glands and other organs Lymphocyte specific
Ex: HSV 1 and 2, varicella-zoster virus

Ex: CMV

HHV6

HHV7

Ex: EBV

HHV8

questions.text: Which of the following is a property of the cell wall of the organism that stains as shown below?

choices.text: Absence of aromatic and sulphur containing amino acids

questions.solution:
The given image shows Gram-negative bacilli, the cell walls of which contain lipopolysaccharides.

The table below gives a comparison of the cell walls of gram-positive and gram-negative bacteria.

  Gram-positive Gram-negative
Teichoic acid, lipoteichoic acid Present Absent
Thickness (Peptidoglycan) Thicker Thinner
Variety of amino acids Few Several
Aromatic and sulphur-containing amino acids Absent Present
Lipopolysaccharides and outer membrane Absent Present

Lipopolysaccharides present on the cell walls of gram-negative bacteria account for the endotoxic activity and O antigen specificity. The outermost layer of the gram-negative bacterial cell wall is called the outer membrane and contains several proteins called outer membrane proteins. 

Gram-positive bacteria contain teichoic acid, which is a major surface antigen containing ribitol or glycerol polymers.

The procedure of Gram staining :

  1. Primary staining with a pararosaniline dye such as crystal violet, methyl violet, or gentian violet.
  2. Application of a dilute solution of iodine - fixes the primary dye by forming a crystal violet-iodine complex to prevent easy removal of dye.
  3. Decolourisation with an organic solvent such as ethanol, acetone, or aniline
  4. Counterstaining with a dye of contrasting colour, such as carbol fuchsin, safranine, or neutral red

The gram-positive cell wall is thicker with several layers of peptidoglycan, which helps retain the primary stain and hence appear violet. The gram-negative cell wall has more lipids, which are dissolved by the decolourising agents, causing rapid decolourisation and taking up the counterstain, hence appearing red. 

Related Pearl: Various stains and their applications in microbiology

A. Simple stains: Provides color contrast but gives same color to all bacteria and cells.

Type of stain Applications
Acidic stains

These include eosin, acid fuchsin, rose bengal, congo red, etc.

Used to stain pathological specimens
Basic stains.

Loeffler’s methylene blue stain is used in Quellung reaction. 

Polychrome methylene blue is used in McFadyean’s reaction.
Neutral stains

Wright and Giemsa stains are Romanowsky stains used to stain peripheral blood and bone marrow smears.  

Giemsa stain is used for histopathological diagnosis of malaria and other protozoan blood parasites.  

 

B. Differential stains: Imparts different colors to different bacteria. (These contain more than one stain).

Type of stain Applications
Gram stain: To differentiate between gram positive (stain purple/violet) and gram negative bacteria (stain pink or red).
Acid-fast stain:  Used in Ziehl–Neelsen staining technique for identification of acid–fast microorganisms such as M. tuberculosis, M. leprae, and Nocardia.
Fluorochrome staining: Auramine-rhodamine is used in fluorochrome staining for screening for tuberculosis.

C. Special stains:

Type of stain Applications
Staining volutin-containing organisms Corynebacterium diphtheriae stained by Albert’s stain. Green colored bacilli showing "chinese-letter" pattern, containing bluish-black metachromatic granules of cells.
Flagella stain Salmonella typhimurium stained by modified Ryu stain to show peritrichous flagella
Endospore stain Used in Schaeffer and Fulton staining technique to stain the endospores, where the primary stain is malachite green, and the counterstain is safranin.
Capsule stain Used in negative staining (Cryptococcus neoformans), McFadyean’s reaction, Polychrome methylene blue (anthrax bacilli).
Silver impregnation Fontana’s silver impregnation method used for staining treponeme and leptospire.
Silver staining Used in Grocott’s – Gomori’s methenamine silver stain. GMS stain is used to identify Pneumocystis jirovecii, which classically appear as crushed ping-pong balls.   Warthin–starry silver stain for spirochetes.
Calcofluor white staining The cell walls of fungi will bind the stain calcofluor white. It is especially useful for the identification of mucor and the causative agents of zygomycosis.  It is also used in staining acanthamoeba
Chance's staining For cell wall demonstration

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents with myoclonic jerks, seizures, and a rapid decline in cognitive functions. Medical records revealed fever with a rash at 1 year of age. The mother said the rash had started behind the ears, progressed to involve the whole body, and resolved on its own. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given case scenario with a classic history of exanthematous fever is suggestive of measles. Seizures, myoclonic jerks, and cognitive dysfunction indicate subacute sclerosing panencephalitis (SSPE).

SSPE is a chronic, progressive demyelinating disease that develops years after measles infection, most often in patients between 5 and 15 years of age. Patients have a history of measles infection at <2 years of age. CSF shows elevated measles antibody levels, and MRI shows increased T2 intensity in white matter. No definitive treatment is available. 

Other complications of measles:

  • Meningoencephalitis
  • Giant-cell pneumonitis
  • Pneumonia
  • Croup
  • Secondary infections - otitis media
  • Protracted diarrhoea
